list-item.p: Identifies Fmp45 as a new regulator of zeocin-induced double-strand breaks.
Fmp45 via Rad9 checkpoint, independent of HR or NHEJ repair pathways.
Fmp45 interacts with Ptc2 to promote Rad53 dephosphorylation.
Fmp45 as a key regulator balancing DNA repair fidelity and cell cycle.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Double-strand breaks (DSBs) are repaired through the coordinated action of DNA damage checkpoint pathways, homologous recombination (HR), and non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) mechanisms. Given the complexity of DSB repair networks, the identification of novel regulatory factors remains essential for a comprehensive understanding of genomic stability maintenance. Fmp45, a membrane protein previously implicated in salt stress response but with no known role in DNA repair, was found to be upregulated in multiple DNA damage-related transcriptomic datasets (GEO: GSE83454, GSE155701, GSE74642). This observation led us to hypothesize that Fmp45 might represent a previously unrecognized component of the DSB repair machinery. In this study, we demonstrate that Fmp45 functions as a zeocin-specific modulator of the DSB response in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Growth phenotypes were analysed to investigate FMP45 deletion (fmp45Δ) and its genetic interactions with other genes, protein expression and Rad53 phosphorylation was assessed by Western blotting, protein localization was analysed by Laser confocal microscopy, cell cycle progression was determined by flow cytometry, and protein–protein interactions was probed yeast two-hybrid assays.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Growth assays revealed that fmp45Δ mutants exhibited hypersensitivity to DSBs induced by zeocin but not to other DNA lesions caused by hydroxyurea, methyl methanesulfonate, 4-nitroquinoline-1-oxide, or camptothecin. Genetic interaction analysis showed that Fmp45 cooperated with checkpoint gene Rad9 but not with HR-related genes (Sae2, Exo1) or NHEJ factor yku70. Laser confocal microscopy confirmed that FMP45 deletion did not impair nuclear localization of Rad51, a key mediator of HR-mediated DNA strand invasion. Further analysis of Rad53 phosphorylation/dephosphorylation dynamics, growth phenotypes of fmp45Δ with phosphatase (ptc2Δ, pph3Δ) and checkpoint effector (rad9Δ, mrc1Δ) mutants, cell cycle profiling, and yeast two-hybrid assays demonstrated that Fmp45 interacts with Ptc2 to promote Rad53 dephosphorylation, thereby preventing excessive cell cycle arrest.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: These findings elucidate a critical checkpoint-phosphatase coordination mechanism ensuring timely DNA damage recovery and genomic stability, identifying Fmp45 as a key regulator balancing DNA repair fidelity with cell cycle resumption following DSBs.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: DNA contains the genetic information essential for constructing an organism, maintaining DNA stability is essential for the survival and proper function of an organism.1 However, spontaneous errors during DNA replication,2 reactive oxygen species (ROS) and reactive nitrogen (RNS),3 ionizing radiation, chemical mutagens, and ultraviolet light4, 5 and other endogenous and exogenous factors can cause DNA damage. These damages can block genome replication and transcription, and unrepaired or improperly repaired DNA damage can lead to mutations or broader genomic instability.6 And it may related with neurodegenerative diseases7 cardiovascular diseases,8 immune deficiency and infertility,9 stem cell dysfunction,10 aging11 and even cancer,12 threatening the survival of cells or biological individuals.

DNA double-strand breaks are among the most lethal forms of DNA damage due to the complexity of their repair.13 DSBs repair mainly through two ways: the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ)14 and Homologous recombination (HR).15 NHEJ can work in all of the cell cycle. During NHEJ, DSBs are recognized by Ku proteins, which then bind to and activate the protein kinases, leading to the recruitment and activation of end-processing enzymes, polymerase, and DNA ligase.14 In contrast, HR occurs primarily in the S and G2 phases of the cell cycle, as it mediates faithful repair by using the homologous sequence as a template.15 In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, HR is initiated by MRX (Mre11-Rad50-Xrs2) complex binds to DNA breaks and then recruits Sae2.16 During Sae2 initiation end resection, the 5′-3′ exonuclease Exo1 and the endonuclease Dna2 are also recruited by the MRX complex to control two partially functionally redundant remote excision pathways, respectively.17 Dna2-mediated excision requires the helicase Sgs1 to open the double helix of DNA from the 5′-3′ direction and cut the 5′-ssDNA that extends from the end of the double-stranded DNA.18 Replication protein A (RPA) then binds to the exposed ssDNA,19 which is then replaced by strand exchange protein Rad51 with the assistance of recombinant mediator proteins Rad52 and Rad55-Rad57 to form a nuclear protein filament that catalyzes homologous pairing and strand invasion. And finally, by polymerases, nucleases, helicases, and other components, DNA ligation and substrate breakdown occur for subsequent repair.15, 20 It has also been shown that the binding state of Ku protein to MRX complex may prevent Exo1 recruitment, Ku inhibits the Exo1- and Sgs1-dependent processing of DNA termini when functional MRX complex or Sae2 protein is lacking.21.

To coordinate repair with cell cycle progression, cells activate a DNA damage checkpoint (DDC), arrest the cell cycle and strive for the time to repair DNA damage.22 Upon DSB formation, the MRX complex recognizes breaks and recruits PIKK kinase Tel1 to activate the TEL1-dependent DNA damage checkpoint.23 Following end resection, signaling transitions from Tel1-dependent to Mec1,24 and Ddc2 interacts with Mec1, allowing Mec1-Ddc2 dimers to recognize and bind to RPA-coated ssDNA complexes.25 Mec1 was activated by the 9–1-1 complex (Ddc1-Rad17-Mec3) and replication protein Dpb11.26 After both Tel1 and Mec1 were activated, Rad9 was recruited to the lesion site as a mediator protein and phosphorylated, followed by Rad53 to the lesion site. Rad9 help Mec1 and Rad53 close to each other and phosphorylate Rad53.27 In the DNA damage checkpoint pathway of Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Rad53 is the most central protein kinase. Fully activated Rad53 will promote the operation of its downstream effector proteins, and then initiate the DNA damage checkpoint and arrest the cell cycle provides sufficient time for DSBs repair process.28 After damage repaired, cell requires deactivation of phosphorylated Rad53 to inactivate the DNA damage checkpoint pathway,29 and PP4 phosphatase complex Pph3-Psy2 and the PP2C-like phosphatase Ptc2/Ptc3 dephosphorylate Rad53 in a redundant manner. Pph3, a PP2A class Ser/Thr protein phosphatase, can form a stable complex with Psy2 that dephosphorylates activated Rad53. The FHA2 domain of Rad53 interacts with Rad9. Psy2, a regulatory subunit of the phosphatase Pph3, specifically binds to this domain and dephosphorylates Rad53. Ptc2 and Ptc3 are highly homologous proteins. Ptc2 directly interacts with Rad53 by binding to the FHA1 domain of Rad53 and plays a role in the deactivation of Rad53.30, 31 Although many molecules and pathways related to DNA damage response and repair have been identified, DNA repair is a complex biological process composed of many protein factors, and there are still many related proteins' functions and mechanisms waiting to be discovered.

Zeocin is an aminoglycopeptide antitumor drug and is also extensively utilized as an inducer of DNA DSBs.32, 33, 34 It achieves this by forming complexes with metal ions such as copper (Cu) and iron (Fe), inserting itself between DNA base pairs, catalyzing the reduction of molecular oxygen to free radicals, and severing the associated DNA double strands, thereby leading to DNA double-strand break.35 Fmp45 is a member of the Sur7 family, which was identified at the apex of the furrowed structure in the MCC (membrane compartment occupied by Can1) domain of the cell membrane in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Fmp45 is co-localized with its homolog transmembrane protein Sur7, which can resist intracellular copper toxicity. It has been found that Fmp45 is expressed at a very low level, but its transcription level increases in a high-salt environment. Furthermore, when Sur7 is deficient, the expression of Fmp45 increases even more, enabling the organism to cope with the high-salt conditions.36 Additionally, Sur7 plays an important role in cell wall synthesis and maintenance of morphology; however, the absence of Fmp45 does not exacerbate cell wall damage. Although both of FMP45 and Sur7 are members of the Sur7 family, their functions do not overlap.37 No evidence has emerged from contemporary research demonstrating Fmp45′s participation in additional functional pathways. By searching the GEO (Gene Expression Omnibus, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/) database, we collected datasets related to DNA damage. These data indicated that in response to various damaging agents, including HU (Hydroxyurea), MMS (Methyl Methanesulfonate), and 4-NQO (4-Nitroquinoline 1-oxide), expression of Fmp45 were all increased in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. That suggested that Fmp45 might be involved in the response to DNA damage.

In the present study, we investigated the sensitivity of fmp45Δ (Fmp45 deletion) to various DNA-damaging agents, including HU, MMS, 4-NQO, and CPT, and found that fmp45Δ was sensitive to Zeocin, which induces DNA double-strand breaks, suggesting a potential role for Fmp45 in the DNA damage response and repair. We also found that after treated with zeocin, the expression of FMP45 was upregulated, fmp45Δ resulted to a deceleration in S phase progression and hyperphosphorylation of the checkpoint effector protein Rad53. Importantly, Fmp45 was not found to be directly involved in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks through HR or NHEJ pathways. Instead, it appears to regulate the activation and inactivation of Rad53 by inhibiting the checkpoint mediator protein Rad9 and through its interaction with the phosphatase Ptc2. In this study, we aim to characterize the role of Fmp45 in the DNA damage response, specifically in the context of Rad53 checkpoint signaling and zeocin-induced stress.

sec.title: Strains and plasmids
sec.p: Genotypes of yeast strains and primers used in this study are listed in Table S1 and Table S2, respectively. All primers were synthesized by Sangon Biotech (Shanghai, China). All plasmids came from Addgene and were ordered by sinozhongyuan (Beijing, China). The deletion strains were made by replaced coding region using the KanMX4/ Hygromycin cassette PCR-amplified with del primers from the pFA6a-KanMX/- hygMX6, and verified by PCR using det primers. Strains were tagged with green fluorescent protein (GFP) by inserting the sequence of GFP-KanMX before the stop codon of genes by PCR-amplified with tag primers from the pFA6a-GFP-KanMX, and verified by PCR using det primers.

sec.title: Yeast growth phenotype assay
sec.p: Overnight cultures were inoculated into new fresh YPD (1 % Yeast extract, 2 % peptone, 2 % dextrose) and diluted into OD600 of 0.2 and then allowed to grow to about OD600 of 1.0. Cells were then serially diluted and manually spotted on YPD plates with or without MMS (M301750, Aladdin, Shanghai, China), HU (H106352, Aladdin, Shanghai, China), CPT (B21343, Yuanye, Shanghai, China), or Zeocin (ant-zn-05, Invivogen). Plates were incubated about 2 days at 30 °C, and image of plate scanned by Epson V600 scanner.

sec.title: SDS-PAGE and Western blot analysis
sec.p: Approximately 4 × 108 Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells in the exponential growth phase were collected, and proteins were extracted as described by Kushnirov38 for detection expression level or by TCA (tri-chloroacetic acid) extraction for detection phosphorylation of Rad53.39 Protein samples were boiled for 5 min, and about 30 μL of samples were loading to 8, 10 or 12 % polyacrylamide gels, and transferred to blot (3010040001, Merck). Anti-Flag monoclonal antibody (D191041, Shanghai Sangon Biotech, Shanghai, China), mouse anti-β-actin monoclonal antibody (AA128, Shanghai Sangon Biotech, Shanghai, China), rabbit anti-Rad53 monoclonal antibody (ab104232, Abcam), Goat anti-mouse IgG (H + L) secondary antibody (A0216, beyotime, Shanghai,China), and goat anti-rabbit IgG (H + L) secondary antibody (A0208, beyotime, Shanghai,China) were purchased and added. The blot was developed with ECL kit (P0018S, beyotime, Shanghai,China) after probed with specific first and second antibodies using Chemiluminescence imaging system (Jiapeng, Shanghai, China). Quantitative analysis of expression of proteins and phosphorylation of Rad53 were performed using ImageJ software (National Institutes of Health, https://imagej.net/ij/download.html).

sec.title: Flow cytometry
sec.p: Log phase yeast cells were synchronized with α-factor (HY-P1482, MedChemExpress, Shanghai, China), released into S phase, collected at different time point, fixed in 70 % ethanol overnight and washed twice in 50 mM sodium citrate (pH 7.0). After incubation with 0.1 mg/mL DNase-free RNase A (B694345, Sangon Biotech, Shanghai, China) for 1 h at 50 °C, followed by addition of 100 U Proteinase K (HY-108717, medchemexpress, Shanghai, China) and further incubation for 1 h at 50 °C. DNA was stained with 20 µg/mL of propidium iodide (R20287, Shyuanye, Shanghai, China) for 30 min, and washed twice in 50 mM sodium citrate (pH 7.0). Then the cells were detected by Novocyte Flow cytometer (Agilent, San Diego, CA, USA) and analyzed with the FlowJo software (BD Biosciences, San Jose, CA, USA).

sec.title: Confocal microscopy
sec.p: Yeast cells were fixed with PEM buffer (R28550, Yuanye Bio-Technology, Shanghai, China) containing 3.7 % (v/v) formaldehyde for 5 min, washed with PEM buffer for 5 min twice, permeabilized with 0.1 % (v/v) Triton X-100 in PEM buffer for 30 sec to achieve partial cell wall removal and cellular permeabilization, and washed with PEM buffer 5 min twice. Nuclear staining was performed using PEM buffer containing 0.05 µg/mL DAPI for 30 min, followed by two final PEM buffer washes. Processed cells were mounted on glass slides using 3 µL aliquots of cell suspension under coverslips for microscopic observation.

For microscopy, a Nikon Ti laser scan confocal microscope with a Plan Apo 40x DIC objective lens was used. DAPI was detected using a laser of 405 nm and a filter of 447 nm. GFP was detected using a laser of 488 nm and an emission filter of 514 nm. Colocalization analysis was implemented through Coloc 2 plugin of Fijis (National Institutes of Health).

sec.title: Fmp45 is involved in the DNA damage caused by genotoxin zeocin.
sec.p:
Three yeast DNA damage-related datasets, GSE83454 (HU), GSE155701 (MMS) and GSE74642 (4-nitroquinoline-1-oxide [4-NQO]), were retrieved from the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) database. These results showed that transcript levels of Fmp45 were up-regulated in Saccharomyces cerevisiae treated with HU, MMS and 4-NQO, suggesting a potential role of FMP45 in the DNA damage response (Fig. 1A).Fig. 1
Fmp45 is involved in the DNA damage caused by genotoxin Zeocin. (A) Gene expression of Fmp45 was treated with HU, MMS and 4-NQO; (B) Growth phenotypes of the wild-type W303 and fmp45Δ yeast strain on the YPD plates and YPD plates containing different DNA damaging agents. (C) The protein expression of FMP45 treated with or without zeocin, ***: P < 0.001.

To test the specific DNA lesion types associated with FMP45 functionality, growth phenotypes assay was conducted using fmp45Δ mutant and WT strains exposed to distinct genotoxic agents. The fmp45Δ exhibited hypersensitivity to zeocin (DNA double-strand break inducer), however, it was not sensitive to HU (replication stress inducer), MMS (alkylation damage inducer), CPT (topoisomerase-I-mediated single-strand break inducer), and 4-NQO (oxidative base damage inducer) (Fig. 1B). In addition, Fmp45 expression was significantly increased under zeocin treatment (Fig. 1C). These results suggest that Fmp45 is involved in the DNA double-strand damage response.

sec.title: Fmp45 likely functions through the DNA damage Checkpoint, not NHEJ/HR, in Zeocin-mediated DNA repair
sec.p:
The repair of DNA DSBs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae is primarily mediated by two conserved pathways: NHEJ, initiated by the Ku complex (Yku70/Yku80) binding to DNA termini, and HR, which involves resection of DNA ends by the MRX complex (Mre11-Rad50-Xrs2) cooperate with Sae2. Subsequent long-range resection by Exo1 exonuclease and Sgs1 helicase generates single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) to facilitate HR.40 The Ku complex competitively inhibits MRX binding to DSBs ends, thereby suppressing resection and HR initiation (Fig. 2A). Growth phenotyping revealed that fmp45Δsae2Δ and fmp45Δexo1Δ double mutants exhibited enhanced sensitivity to genotoxic agents compared to their single mutants (Fig. 2B and C), suggesting Fmp45 functions independently of Sae2 and Exo1. The yku70Δ single and fmp45Δyku70Δ double mutant showed comparable sensitivity to wild-type W303 but less sensitivity to fmp45Δ at low zeocin concentrations (30 µg/mL), and, at elevated zeocin doses (80 µg/mL), fmp45Δyku70Δ exhibited slight less sensitivity than yku70Δ, and much less sensitivity than fmp45Δ (Fig. 2D). The results demonstrate that yeast preferentially employs HR to repair DSBs, while Fmp45 appears to participate in DSBs repair through alternative pathways distinct from neither HR nor NHEJ.Fig. 2
FMP45 does not directly participate in the initiation of non-homologous end joining or homologous recombination repair pathways. (A) Schematic representation of canonical DNA double-strand break repair mechanisms; (B-D) Growth phenotypes of 10-fold serial dilutions of the culture of isogenic yeast strains treated with zeocin; (B) W303, fmp45Δ, fmp45Δsae2Δ, sae2Δ, and rad9Δ; (C) W303, fmp45Δ, fmp45Δexo1Δ, exo1Δ, and rad9Δ; (D) W303, fmp45Δ, fmp45Δyku70Δ, yku70Δ, and rad9Δ. (E) Subcellular localization of Rad51-EGFP fusion protein was analyzed by confocal microscopy (Nikon Ti, 40 × ) in W303 and fmp45Δ strains with or without zeocin treatment. Nuclei were counterstained with DAPI (Scale bar: 5 μm); (F-I) Quantitative colocalization analysis of Rad51 (green) and nuclei (blue). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

To assess Fmp45′s role in Rad51 recruitment, EGFP-tagged Rad51 localization was analyzed by confocal microscopy in wild-type and fmp45Δ strains. In untreated cells, Rad51-EGFP displayed diffuse nuclear distribution. After zeocin treatment, both strains exhibited Rad51 foci formation and colocalized with chromatin DNA (Fig. 2E–I), indicating Fmp45 does not regulate Rad51 recruitment or filament formation.

DSBs activate the Mec1-dependent DNA damage checkpoint, wherein adaptors Mrc1 (replication stress) or Rad9 (DSBs) relay signals to effector kinase Rad53, triggering cell cycle arrest. And the PP4 phosphatase complex (Pph3-Psy2) and PP2C-like phosphatases (Ptc2/Ptc3) mediate Rad53 dephosphorylation through distinct pathways to terminate checkpoint signaling following successful damage repair (Fig. 2A). As shown in Fig. 3A, the fmp45Δmrc1Δ double mutant exhibited significantly increased zeocin sensitivity compared to either fmp45Δ or mrc1Δ single mutants. Conversely, the fmp45Δrad9Δ double mutant in Fig. 3B demonstrated comparable sensitivity to its respective single mutants. These results suggest a synergistic genetic interaction between Mrc1 and Fmp45 deletions, implying their functional independence within distinct pathways. In contrast, the non-additive phenotype of fmp45Δrad9Δ indicates their coordinated action within a shared pathway.Fig. 3
Fmp45 participates in zeocin-induced DNA repair through the DNA damage checkpoint pathway. Growth phenotypes of 10-fold serial dilutions of the culture of isogenic yeast strains treated with zeocin at 30 °C for two days. (A) W303, fmp45Δ, fmp45Δmrc1Δ, mrc1Δ, and rad9Δ. (B) W303, fmp45Δ, fmp45Δrad9Δ, and rad9Δ. (C) W303, fmp45Δ, fmp45Δpph3Δ, pph3Δ, rad9Δ. (D) W303, fmp45Δ, fmp45Δptc2Δ, ptc2Δ, and rad9Δ.

Further characterization of checkpoint termination mechanisms revealed differential genetic dependencies. The fmp45Δpph3Δ double mutant (Fig. 3C) showed exacerbated DNA damage sensitivity relative to single mutants, indicating non-redundant roles of Fmp45 and the PP4 complex (Pph3-Psy2) in checkpoint regulation. Conversely, the fmp45Δptc2Δ double mutant (Fig. 3D) phenocopied the sensitivity profile of ptc2Δ alone, implying functional overlap between Fmp45 and the PP2C-like phosphatase Ptc2 in checkpoint inactivation.

sec.title: Fmp45 attenuates Rad9-Dependent signaling to prevent Rad53 hyperphosphorylation and Preserve cell cycle progression
sec.p:
In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, DNA damage activates the Mec1-dependent checkpoint pathway, leading to phosphorylation of the effector kinase Rad53. This post-translational modification initiates cell cycle arrest to facilitate DNA repair while safeguarding against the transmission of damaged genetic material. To assess Fmp45′s role in cell cycle regulation, G1-synchronized cells were released into zeocin-containing medium. Flow cytometric analysis revealed significantly delayed cell cycle progression in fmp45Δ mutants compared to WT W303, suggesting Fmp45 deficiency may elicit checkpoint-associated responses (Fig. 4A). As Rad53 phosphorylation mediates cell cycle arrest, we hypothesized that Fmp45 deletion might influence Rad53 modification status. Western blot demonstrated Rad53 hyperphosphorylation in fmp45Δ mutants relative to WT W303 following zeocin exposure, indicating checkpoint hyperactivation in the absence of Fmp45 (Fig. 4B).Fig. 4
Fmp45 protects cell cycle progression by negatively regulating Rad9 and preventing Rad53 from being hyperphosphorylated. (A, C, E) The yeast strain was arrested in the G1 phase with the alpha factor, then the cells were collected, washed and resuspended with fresh YPD medium containing zeocin, and cells were collected at different time points, and flow cytometry was used to detect the progression of the cell cycle. (A) Cell cycle of W303 and fmp45Δ; (B) The phosphorylation levels of Rad53 of W303 and fmp45Δ. (C) Cell cycle of W303, fmp45Δ, mrc1Δ and fmp45Δmrc1Δ. (D) The phosphorylation level of Rad53 of W303, fmp45Δ, mrc1Δ and fmp45Δmrc1Δ treated with zeocin. (E) Cell cycle of W303, fmp45Δ, rad9Δ and fmp45Δrad9Δ. (F) The phosphorylation level of Rad53 of W303, fmp45Δ, rad9Δ and fmp45Δrad9Δ.

Mrc1 and Rad9, two primary mediator proteins of the DNA damage checkpoint pathway, recruit the effector kinase Rad53 and cooperatively facilitate Mec1-dependent phosphorylation for full activation of Rad53. Flow cytometry analysis revealed that cell cycle progression was significantly delayed in the fmp45Δmrc1Δ double mutant strain, as well as in the mrc1Δ and fmp45Δ single mutant strains, compared to the WT W303 (Fig. 4C). Consistently, Western blot demonstrated that under zeocin-induced DNA damage, the fmp45Δmrc1Δ double mutant, fmp45Δ and mrc1Δ single mutants exhibited elevated levels of Rad53 phosphorylation relative to WT cells (Fig. 4D). These results suggest that neither Fmp45 nor Mrc1 is required for the transmission of phosphorylation signals to Rad53 in response to zeocin-induced DSBs.

Rad9 is another mediator protein of the DNA damage checkpoint pathway. Flow cytometry analysis revealed that the fmp45Δrad9Δ double mutant and rad9Δ single mutant strains exhibited accelerated cell cycle progression compared to the fmp45Δ single mutant and WT W303 following 30 min zeocin treatment. Notably, the fmp45Δ single mutant displayed more pronounced cell cycle arrest than other strains after 60 min zeocin exposure (Fig. 4E). Western blot analysis demonstrated that deletion of Rad9 abolished phosphorylation levels in both WT W303 and fmp45Δ strains. These results indicate that Rad9-mediated DNA damage checkpoint signaling is required for Rad53 phosphorylation-dependent cell cycle arrest during zeocin-induced DSBs repair. Conversely, Rad53 phosphorylation in the fmp45Δ mutant exceeded WT levels, suggesting that Fmp45 may protect Rad53 from hyperphosphorylation by attenuating Rad9-mediated checkpoint signaling, thereby facilitating timely cell cycle resumption following DNA repair completion (Fig. 4F).

sec.title: FMP45 facilitates Rad53 dephosphorylation-mediated inactivation through the Ptc2 pathway rather than the Pph3 pathway to restore normal cell cycle progression
sec.p:
Following DNA repair, Rad53 undergoes dephosphorylation mediated primarily by the PP4 phosphatase complex (PPH3-PSY2) and PP2C-like phosphatases (PTC2/PTC3), facilitating cell cycle recovery. To investigate Fmp45′s role in Rad53 dephosphorylation, we analyzed Rad53 phosphorylation dynamics via Western blot. Zeocin-induced DNA damage triggered initial Rad53 hyperphosphorylation. Subsequent recovery in non-damaging conditions revealed progressive dephosphorylation in WT W303, indicative of successful DNA repair and Rad53 inactivation. In contrast, the fmp45Δ mutant maintained persistently elevated Rad53 phosphorylation throughout the 3 h recovery period (Fig. 5A), demonstrating impaired dephosphorylation.Fig. 5
FMP45 mediates dephosphorylation inactivation of Rad53 through the Ptc2 pathway to restore the cell cycle. (A) Phosphorylation of Rad53 of W303 and fmp45Δ during zeocin induced DNA repair; (B) Phosphorylation of Rad53 of W303, fmp45Δ, pph3Δ, fmp45Δpph3Δ during zeocin induced DNA repair; (C) Phosphorylation of Rad53 of W303, fmp45Δ, ptc2Δ, fmp45Δptc2Δ during zeocin induced DNA repair; (D) Dephosphorylation of Rad53 of W303, fmp45Δ, ptc2Δ, fmp45Δptc2 at different time points during DNA repair with zeocin.

To delineate whether Fmp45 operates through the PP4 complex (PPH3-PSY2) or PP2C-like phosphatases (PTC2/PTC3), we assessed Rad53 phosphorylation in fmp45Δpph3Δ double mutants under 3 h zeocin treatment. The fmp45Δpph3Δ strain exhibited significantly higher Rad53 phosphorylation compared to fmp45Δ or pph3Δ single mutants (Fig. 5B), suggesting functional independence between Fmp45 and Pph3. Conversely, fmp45Δptc2Δ double mutants showed Rad53 phosphorylation patterns with fmp45Δ and ptc2Δ single mutants under identical conditions (Fig. 5C), implying pathway convergence between Fmp45 and Ptc2. In addition, DNA damage recovery assay (zeocin removal after 3 h treatment) demonstrated similar Rad53 dephosphorylation kinetics in fmp45Δptc2Δ, fmp45Δ, and ptc2Δ strains at both 1.5 h and 3 h time points (Fig. 5D). These data collectively demonstrate that Fmp45 operates in the same dephosphorylation pathway as Ptc2 to regulate Rad53 inactivation.

sec.title: Fmp45 interacts with Rad53 and Ptc2 to regulate the dephosphorylation of Rad53
sec.p: Both the yeast two-hybrid (Y2H) assay and co-immunoprecipitation (co-IP) are widely used to detect protein–protein interactions. However, the Y2H system offers particular advantages in capturing mutual, transient, and weak interactions under physiological conditions. In this study, we applied the Y2H approach to probe the direct and dynamic interplay among Fmp45, Rad53, and Ptc2. In the Y2HGold yeast strain, Mel1 expression, which catalyzes X-α-gal conversion to blue chromogenic products, is controlled by the GAL4 promoter. This system employs two hybrid proteins: one fused to the GAL4 DNA-binding domain (BD) and the other to the activation domain (AD). Protein-protein interaction reconstitutes GAL4-dependent transcriptional activation, resulting in blue colony formation on X-α-gal-containing plates. In this study, we constructed BD-Fmp45 and AD-Rad53/AD-Ptc2 fusion proteins for yeast two-hybrid analysis using blue-white screening.

On SD/-Leu/-Trp/X-α-gal plates, colonies co-expressing AD-Rad53 and BD-Fmp45 exhibited blue coloration both with and without zeocin supplementation (Fig. 6A). Similar interaction patterns were observed for AD-Ptc2 and BD-Fmp45 combinations (Fig. 6B), demonstrating physical interaction between Fmp45 and Ptc2. This finding aligned with our DNA damage recovery assay showing equivalent Rad53 dephosphorylation kinetics in fmp45Δptc2Δ, fmp45Δ, and ptc2Δ mutants (Fig. 5D), collectively indicating that Fmp45 cooperates with Ptc2 to mediate Rad53 dephosphorylation.Fig. 6
Fmp45 interacts with Rad53 and Ptc2 to regulate the dephosphorylation of Rad53. Yeast two-hybrid assay was used to detect the interaction between Fmp45 and Rad53 (A), and between Fmp45 and Ptc2 (B).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Current understanding of Fmp45 function remains limited. In Candida albicans, Fmp45 represents a paralog closely related to SUR7, with both proteins localized to plasma membrane domains.37 Functional studies indicate that Sur7 and Fmp45 share similar roles in cellular adaptation to environmental stressors, including elevated temperature and osmotic pressure.36 In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Fmp45 has been characterized as a mitochondrial integral membrane protein belonging to the Sur7 family, where it contributes significantly to cell wall biosynthesis. Disruption of Fmp45 leads to impaired cell wall integrity.41 This study elucidates the role of Fmp45 in DDR, particularly in the context of DSBs induced by the genotoxin zeocin. Our analysis of yeast transcriptomic datasets (GSE83454, GSE155701, GSE74642) revealed that Fmp45 expression is upregulated in response to diverse DNA-damaging agents, including HU, MMS, CPT and 4-NQO, suggesting its broad involvement in DDR (Fig. 1A). However, phenotypic assays demonstrated that the fmp45Δ mutant exhibits selective hypersensitivity to zeocin, while not resistance to HU, MMS, CPT, 4-NQO (Fig. 1B). This phenotypic specificity can be understood in light of the distinct DNA lesions generated by these genotoxins. HU inhibits ribonucleotide reductase (RNR), depleting dNTP pools and causing replication fork stalling without direct DNA breakage.42 MMS alkylates bases such as guanine and adenine, leading primarily to base mispairing and replication blocks.43 CPT traps topoisomerase I-DNA complexes, which collapse upon replication fork collision to generate DSBs.44, 45 4NQO, an ultraviolet light-mimetic agent, can produce chromosomal breaks or aberrations, and DNA adducts.46, 47 Nevertheless, these breaks are replication-dependent and structurally distinct from those directly induced by zeocin. Zeocin acts through a metal-dependent mechanism to introduce direct single- and double-strand DNA nicks that are rapidly converted into DSBs, which represent the predominant lethal lesion.48 The fact that fmp45Δ is hypersensitive only to zeocin—an agent that directly and abundantly produces DSBs—highlights a specific role for Fmp45 in countering this particular type of DNA damage, coupled with the observed upregulation of Fmp45 upon zeocin treatment (Fig. 1C), strongly implicates Fmp45 in DSBs repair.

Despite the central role of HR and NHEJ in DSBs repair,49 our genetic interaction studies demonstrate that Fmp45 functions independently of these pathways. The synthetic hypersensitivity of fmp45Δsae2Δ and fmp45Δexo1Δ double mutants (Fig. 2B–C) indicates that Fmp45 does not act redundantly with the resection machinery (Sae2, Exo1) required for HR. Furthermore, fmp45Δyku70Δ mutants exhibited intermediate sensitivity to zeocin compared to fmp45Δ and yku70Δ (Fig. 2D), suggesting partial functional overlap with NHEJ but no direct role in this pathway. Critically, Rad51-EGFP foci formation remained intact in fmp45Δ cells after zeocin exposure (Fig. 2E–I), confirming that Fmp45 does not influence HR initiation or Rad51 filament assembly. These findings collectively position Fmp45 within a non-canonical repair mechanism, distinct from both HR and NHEJ, likely interfacing with checkpoint signalling rather than direct DNA repair.

Zeocin-induced DSBs trigger robust activation of the Mec1-dependent DNA damage checkpoint, mediated by adaptor proteins Rad9 and Mrc1. Strikingly, fmp45Δ mutants exhibited prolonged cell cycle arrest (Fig. 4A) and hyperphosphorylation of Rad53 (Fig. 4B), indicative of checkpoint hyperactivation. Genetic interaction analyses revealed that fmp45Δrad9Δ phenocopied rad9Δ (Fig. 3B), whereas fmp45Δmrc1Δ displayed synthetic sensitivity (Fig. 3A), suggesting Fmp45 functions in the same pathway as Rad9 but independently of Mrc1. Notably, Rad53 phosphorylation in fmp45Δ surpassed WT levels (Fig. 4F), implying that Fmp45 dampens Rad9-mediated signaling to prevent excessive Rad53 activation. This regulatory role ensures balanced checkpoint activity, allowing timely cell cycle progression once repair is complete.

Checkpoint termination requires Rad53 dephosphorylation, mediated redundantly by the PP4 complex (Pph3-Psy2) and PP2C-like phosphatases (Ptc2/Ptc3).31, 50 Persistent Rad53 phosphorylation in fmp45Δ during recovery (Fig. 5A) highlighted Fmp45′s critical role in checkpoint inactivation. Genetic epistasis analysis revealed that fmp45Δptc2Δ phenocopied ptc2Δ (Fig. 3D, Fig. 5C–D), whereas fmp45Δpph3Δ exhibited synthetic sensitivity (Fig. 3C). These data demonstrate that Fmp45 operates specifically within the Ptc2 pathway to promote Rad53 dephosphorylation. This functional convergence is further supported by yeast two-hybrid assays showing direct physical interaction between Fmp45 and Ptc2 (Fig. 6B), positioning Fmp45 as a co-regulator of Ptc2-mediated checkpoint silencing.

Protein interaction studies confirmed that Fmp45 binds directly to both Rad53 and Ptc2 (Fig. 6A–B), providing a mechanistic basis for its role in checkpoint regulation. To investigate potential transcriptional regulation mechanisms, we analyzed transcriptomes comparing fmp45Δand WT under basal conditions (GSE8624). Core DNA repair genes showed minimal expression alterations, while significant changes occurred in cell cycle regulators (Fig. S1), consistent with Fmp45′s role in cell cycle control. These findings suggest Fmp45 modulates checkpoint signaling primarily through protein interactions rather than transcriptional regulation.This tripartite interaction likely enables Fmp45 to scaffold Rad53 and Ptc2, facilitating efficient dephosphorylation of Rad53 following DSBs repair. The absence of Fmp45 disrupts this coordination, leading to sustained Rad53 phosphorylation and delayed cell cycle resumption (Fig. 4A, Fig. 5A). These interactions underscore Fmp45′s dual function: modulating Rad9-dependent checkpoint activation and enhancing Ptc2-mediated inactivation, thereby ensuring precise control over DNA damage signaling.

Our findings open several avenues for future exploration. Therapeutically, the Fmp45-Ptc2 interface may offer opportunities to disrupt checkpoint recovery in malignancies − targeting this axis could hypersensitize cancer cells to genotoxic therapies. In synthetic biology, engineered Fmp45 modules could potentially optimize cell-cycle control in industrial strains. Meanwhile, Fmp45 overexpression in production yeast may confer resistance to DNA-damaging fermentation byproducts. Most importantly, this work suggests an evolutionarily conserved paradigm where Sur7-family proteins might moonlight as DDR regulators beyond their canonical roles.

In summary, our study demonstrates that Fmp45 participates in the cellular response to zeocin-induced DNA DSBs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, but not through canonical DSBs repair pathways such as HR or NHEJ. Instead, Fmp45 functions through the DDC pathway to regulate cell cycle progression. Mechanistically, Fmp45 attenuates Rad9-dependent checkpoint signalling, thereby restraining hyperactivation of the effector kinase Rad53 and preventing prolonged cell cycle arrest. Furthermore, Fmp45 directly interacts with Rad53 and synergizes with the PP2C-like phosphatase Ptc2 to facilitate Rad53 dephosphorylation, ensuring timely checkpoint inactivation and resumption of normal cell cycle progression post-repair (Fig. S2). Our study established Fmp45 as a key factor in the dynamic regulation of checkpoint in DSBs response, and proposed a “repair-signal-cycle recovery” synergy model, which deepened the understanding of the complexity of DDR network and laid a theoretical foundation for intervention strategies targeting checkpoint regulation.
